titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.26 Richmond, Va. Friday, January 30, 1863 price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter Cents Per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: The street and other Rumors yesterday.
div3.p:
Yesterday during the day some excitement was created by the announcement that Commissioners had arrived in this city, from the States of Illinois and Indiana, invested with authority to negotiate a treaty of alliance between those States and the States of the Confederacy within thirty days, unless peace propositions were sooner made by the Administration at Washington.
It was further alleged that the action of the States in question was based upon a deep seated opposition in the emancipation proclamation of Lincoln.
We are inclined to believe, as the result of inquiry on the subject, that gentleman from Illinois and Indiana have recently arrived in this city, but that they came accredited with the power them is not probably from the fact that we have no account of any States action inciting to the appointment of such Commissioners.
After the adjournment of the lower House of Congress yesterday, Mr. Peote, of Tenn, to the House, and ...

div3.head: Reported raid upon the salt Works.
div3.p: The Lynchburg from the Mail

div3.head: The Latest Northern
div3.p:
--dates are to the 26th present.
Major F. J. Boggs, who is now operating near Suffolk, will accept our thanks for lies for late Northern papers.

div3.head: [correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch]
div3.p:
A Yankee paper came over yesterday of the 26th, the first for several days.
It informs us that their great "advance movement" returned Sunday night to Falmouth, after marching to Backs's ford, four miles up the river.
They found the approaches impassable.
The mud was too deep, and is getting deeper daily.
Doubtless they marched nine miles, and discovered the river obstructed on both rides — Lee on this, bad roads on the other, and more water than they experted.
My opinion is, the worst impediment on their side is want of confidences among their own men. Their army is backed and won't fight.
No mention is made of Burnside's reported removal.
The probable "soft water" will furnish an into which this boasted fee will sink out of sight, and we shall have no more fighting here this session.
Burnside's assertion that Lee's army is diminished by drafts sent West and South, cannot receive men who can see that rifle pits and to the strength of our forces since the fight of the 13th ult. The jaws of certain destruction are opened wider, and the pit of death is digged deeper to receive them.
They, too, occasionally dig rifle pits on their side, for defence in case cross over.
To-day our boys were digging in the upper and on town, and alarmed the dark considerably.
They say while folks are mighty foolish, killing each other; as if they did not die fast enough anyhow — They think, too, that the daily performances by the sand may exasperate the Yankees to fire on the town again.
Except among them and the foolish people in Richmond there is no commotion or excitement.
We get along very quietly and comfortably, and shall not be disturbed when they march down the river, as the noise and rachet they kicked up last night seems to indicate.
The rain has reinforced" us, and it is still going on. Had will accomplish their destruction and return them to "the vile due, from which they sprang. "

The Yankee correspondent was an eye witness, and is eloquent on Stafford mire.
According to his account it will take them three weeks to day and themselves clean again.
They got one cannon only to the river, and it took twenty horses and all the men who could get hold to drug it back up the bank.
Their new roads are knee deep already and very soon the bottoms will drop out entirely and thus "active winter campaign. " Their down-the-river excursion, when they make it, will have the same history and result, depend upon it.

I have said nothing of Fredericksburg "sufferers" They have been "said and sung," and preached over, and talked about, until the public is with the them" The army which has witnessed in town and country more Illustrations and exhibitions of distress have been most liberal.-- The "land, " I hear, is large in numbers and reckoned by thousand.
But while prices are so enormous, the real effective aid is much less in value than appears in print, and scarcely reaches the generous donations made in former times by the of the South to those whom and wide-spread sorrow has . When whole communities come to grief, and suffering has been so severe and universal, it is right the burden should be shared by those whose and homes Providence has .--Although the excitement and novelty are paid and there is less to of the cup. I have yet to hear the first murmur or regret.
In some instances heavier has been added the homeless have followed loved once to their "last homes" I have just heard of a worthy impoverished by the bombardment, recently here of his oldest daughter, dying of by exposure on that terrible moving.
No "contribution" his grief, although friends share in his sorrow.

Another accidental fire on Saturday consumed three or four more homes on Caroline street and added to the desolation of the scene this ancient It certainly has the from which to "rise phœ" when happier days dawn upon us, in the meantime we are almost destroyed," but not "cost down.,"

That Yankee paper also reported to Yankee gunboat sunk by our batteries at Ford Hudson If our facilities here do not improve several more gunboats may be destroyed before you get this epistle, so consider them reported and imagine the particulars.

The rain soaked into the damp ground all night long.
Every drop belied us. As daybreak the show storm set in, and is still I predict, it will not only arrest Burnside's movements, but will compel him to evacuate.

div4.head: Senate.
div4.p: --The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock M. by Mr. Hunter, and opened with prayer by Rev. Mr. Peterkin, of Episcopal Church.
The following resolutions were offered:
By Mr. Hortch, of A. C.--

q.p: Resolved, That, in view of the of the currency, the Committees on the Judiciary instructed to inquire into the propriety of so amending the a in relation to the sequentration of the estates, &c., of alien enemies as to require the payment to the Government at an early day of moneys due to said enemies.

bibl.n: By Mr. Hortch, of A. C

div4.p:
Resolved, further, That the committee inquire into the propriety of allowing citizens who have lost property by the enemy, and who are indebted to alien enemies, to set off their losses against said indebtedness.
Agreed to.
By Mr. Brown, of Miss.--

Resolved, That the Secretary of War be requested to report whether officers of the army not on duty in the field, has performing electrical or other duties at Richmond and other places, do not receive in the war of commutation for quarters, fuel, ferage for horses&c., such sums of money as to make their monthly pay largely the pay of officers of the same grade serving in the field.
And that sold committee further inquire whether officers duty, as aforesaid, have been allowed to purchase clothing from the Government fold; and, for her if it is that officers performing clerical and other duties in Richmond, are allowed horses according to their rack and whether such horses are kept .

The Senate resumed the consideration of the unfinished business of yesterday, viz: the bill to organize the Supreme Court of the Confederate States, the pending question being the amendments proposed by Mr. Clay, of Ala., repealing the 45th and 46th sections of the act of the Provisional Congress defining the at the Supreme Court. Mr. Phelan, or Miss.
spoke is opposition to the amendment from fifteen minutes past 12 to half past 2 o'clock, and, concluding his argument, the floor was obtained by Mr. Semmes, of La., on whose motion the Senate went into Executive session.
At 3 o'clock the doors were thrown open, and the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Moore.
The Chair laid before the House a communication from the President, transmitting an estimate from the Secretary of War of the sum required for the Ordnance Department. Referred.
Mr. Dargan, of Ala., introduced a bill, which was referred to the Judiciary Committee, to provide for the taking of testimony in certain .

Mr. Corry of Ala., offered a resolution that the Committee of Ways and Means inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill for duties exports.
Agreed to.
Mr. Clupton, of Ala., introduced a bill to repeal the laws of . Referred to the Judiciary Committee.

Mr. Foster, of Ala., offered a resolution that the Committee on Quartermaster and Commissary Departments be to inquire into the expediency of the Nashville, and Decator Railroad from columbia, Tenn., to Decator, Ala.--Agreed to.
Mr. Foster also offered the following lot of resolution:

Resolved, That Congress appreciates with no ordinary feelings the bold and daring attack made by Gen. Wheeler and his command the enemy's transports and gunboats on the Cumberland river, for the of the enterprise, Gen. Wheeler, his, officers, and men, are eminently entitled to the than of this Congress.
Referred to Military Committee.
Also, a resolution that sessions be done away with, and that all business transact by this shall for the future be with open doors.-- Laid over.

Mr. Royston, of Ark, presented a bill to and promote the efficiency of the branch of the military service.
Referred.

Mr. Foreton, of Ark, also offered a resolution that the Committee on Military Affairs be requested to report back to this House a to them by this House at last session making provisions for the maintenance and support of indigent widows and other indigent families having sons or in the army of the Confederate States.-- Agreed to.
Mr. Holt, of Georgia, offered a resolution that the Judiciary Committee be requested to if there be any

Mr. of Georgia offered a resolution that Committee on Military affairs inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill providing for the payment of Provost Marshals appointed from civil life for service actually rendered.
Agreed to

Mr. Whight, of Georgia introduced a bill to prevent the conscription of officers resigning their common is on account of motions received or dis contraction in the service of their county. -- Referred to the Military committee.

Also, a bill to provide compensation for horses lost in the service of the Confederate States.
Referred to the Committee on Quartermaster's Department.

Mr. Conrad, of La., offered a resolution that the President be requested to inform this House whether one -- Broad well has been authorized to make purchases of supplies particularly of sugar and salt, for the Commissary Department if so, whether said Broadwell holds any office in said Department, and what office &c. Agreed to.
Mr. Read, of Ky., offered a resolution that the Committee on Public Buildings be instructed to cause the gallery of this had to be removed.
After an amusing , which lasted some half hour, this resolution was referred, with instructions, to the Committee on Buildings.

The morning hour having expired, the call of the States was suspended and Mr. Royston, of Ark., called for the special order being the bill to declare what persons shall be exempt from enrollment for military duty.

The House resolved itself into Committee of the Whole, (Mr. Curry, of Ala., the chair.) the question being upon the amendment of Mr. Gartred, of Ga., "that no person shall be enrolled who has a substitute in the army, furnished in accordance with orders heretofore issued by the Secretary of War."
Mr. Singleton, of Miss., addressed the House in opposition to the amendment, and, at the conclusion of his remarks, the Committee , and the Chairman reported that no conclusion had been reached.
On motion of Mr. Jones, of Tenn., the House went into secret reason.

div4.head: Senate
div4.p: --The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock M. and opened with prayer.
Sundry bills, whose passage was communicated from the House, were taken up and concerned in by the Senate.

A message was received from the Governor, transmitting a communication forwarded by the Executive to Abraham Lincoln President of the United States, in relation to the imprisonment in the North of Col. Zarvous, without the privilege of exchange, while entitled to it by the commission which he holds as an officer in the service of the State of Virginia . The Governor states that, in retaliation, he will hold all Abolition prisoners captured by the State Line.
Certain loyal citizens of the Western part of the State having been arrested and put in the Washington, D, C, by the minions of Lincoln, it will serve as all additional incentive to retain the parties captured by the State Line.
The Governor had written to this effect to Abraham Lincoln, and a sufficient time having for an answer and none arriving he feels constrained to lay the matter before the General Assembly.
Referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.
The the salaries of problem officers of the members to offer amendments.

Mr. Nash submitted a preamble and resolution relative to some charge brought by evil disposed persons against Gov. Litcher, claiming that he had obstructed the Confederate Congress in doing its work by guarding the State Capitol at night, and forbidding the Congressional employees to lurk about it offer . The resolutions call for a copy of Gov. L's latter to the Speaker of the House of Representatives on the subject.
Adopted.
The bill amending and to an acting an ordinance of the Convention relative to Aids of the Governor was amended and laid on the table.
Bill appropriating $3,000 for increased hospital accommodations at Va. Military Institute being on its passage, was strongly opposed and finally laid on the table.

House bill providing for the discharge from active military service of persons who have furnished substitutes, was taken up, amended and passed; also, authorizing the bank of Rockingham to increase its comingout land; incorporating the Richmond and New Turnpike company in Henrico county, and for the relief of the Sergeants of the cities of and Petersburg.

Resolutions of inquiry into expediency were offered as follows viz: By Mr. Christian of Middle sex, of exempting from all slaves who have escaped from their owners to the public enemy; by Mr. Armstrong of providing by law for the more certain and speedy of all persons who shall, without proper authority, the property of citizens of Virginia; by Mr. Robertson, of examining into the porter claimed by the Confederate Government to sequestrate within the limits of the State of Virginia the property of alien enemies and to hold, sell or dispose of the same, by Mr. Armstrong, inquiring whether the money heretofore appropriated to the Virginia Military Institute has been properly expended and for that purpose empowering the Committee on Military Affairs to send for persons and papers.
On motion of Mr. Alderson, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock, and was opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Burrows.

The Senate bill to amend and re-enact the Code of Virginia so as in the absence of the Commandant of the Public Guard to allow the next in command, upon whom may devolve the duties of the post, to receive all the pay and emoluments pertaining to the Commandant.
Laid upon the table.

Senate bill changing the Code so as to allow but one Major to a regiment.
Referred.

Resolutions of Inquiry.--The following resolutions of inquiry were submitted to the House; By Mr. Prince, into the expediency of brading out all children of free negroes; by Mr. Lively into the expediency of inquiring whether any legislation is necessary to secure the property of alien citizens.
and whether it can be confiscated to the Confederate Government.

Mr. Barbour stated that some days previous the House had elected a Doors --a gentleman nominated by himself, Mr. ,--and as that gentleman had not yet accepted, he moved that the office be declared vacant, which was agreed to.
On motion of Mr. Wynne, the House proceeded to fill the vacancy.

Several gentleman were put in nomination for the post, when the Clerk proceeded with the roll call, which resulted in the choice of Mr. W. R. Freeman, of Richmond, and was so announced by the speaker.

A message was received from Governor Letcher stating that a flag of truce having arrived yesterday, and no reply having been received from Abraham Lincoln to a communication from himself relative to the arrest and imprisonment of Col. Zarvous, be that no such reply was intended, and be therefore communicated to the House the papers called for some days ago.
The Speaker announced a confidential communication from the Governor, when.
On motion of Mr. Ruther , the House went into secret session to consider the same.
After fifteen of minutes that occupied the doors were again opened.
On motion of Mr. Hopkins, the order of the day (the bill for the suppression of extortion) was taken up.
Mr. Hunter opposed the bill at some , as be all not believe it within the power of legislative to control the evil therein complained of.

Mr. Hopkins followed in advocacy of the He said it was subject which was most affecting the interests of the Confederacy, and should be put down, and it was the duty of this House to attend to that once.

Mr. Anderson, of Botelpart, also advocated the bill, citing various instances illustrative of the gross extortion which was being practiced upon it a people.
Mr. Anderson suspended his remarked .
On motion of Mr. Barbour, the further consideration of the bill was postponed until o'clock to-morrow, to be continued from day to-day until disposed of.

A motion was made by Mr. Barbour and carried calling upon the or that a list of the officers and men of the Public Guard, the pay and his reasons for the to pay to Lt. B. S. Gay the pay and of commandant of that past.
On motion, the House adjourned.

div4.head: Position of Affairs in Missouri.
div4.p:
The Jackson (Miss) Crisis publishes some interesting intelligence from a gentleman just from Missouri.
The true-hearted Southern people of the State are as hopeful and sanguine of the final success of our cause as our brave soldiers here in the army.
The people do not feel that they are part and parcel of the Lincoln empire, but are waiting patiently for the day to arrive when they can openly avow their allegiance to the Confederacy.
The late elections in the State, in which the Abolitionists were successful, have only caused the people to set a higher estimate upon the value of Southern independence.
The sentiments of the true Southern people have not been changed by the tyranny of a military Government, while the eyes of many of the former Union men have been opened to ace the enormity of Federal usurpations, and their views have been recordingly changed.
The Crisis says:

q.p: The late elections do, by no mean, reflect the sentiment of the people, but few, comparatively, of the Southern men participated in the election-- where they did they voted for men known to be Southern in sentiment.

div4.p:
Doolphan and Wott, the Senator and Representative, during Gen. Price's stay in Northwest Missouri, took their negroes to Arkansa and left them there while they returned home to enjoy quiet and peace.
Whilst the canvass was going on to Platte, Curtis went into Arkansas, seized their negroes and freed them.

In Clay, James H. Moss commands a Federal regiment, and is stationed at Liberty.
Col. Doolphan is pursuing his old course, taking no active part either one way or another.

In Buchanan, Willard H. Hall is Brigadier General commanding the militia of the district.
He superceded B. F. Losen, who was elected to Congress Hall is also Lieutenant-Governor of the State under the Provisional Government.
Col. Wm. R. Pennick, in command of a regiment of militia, not long since left St. Joseph with his troops, in search of "bush ," and having reached Clay county, arrested Charles Pullus, who left Buchanan in company with Capt. Gibson for the Southern army.
Pullis was taken to Liberty, a most trial was gone through with, and he was condemned to be hung.
He offered to prove that he was a regularly enlined Confederate soldier, but was denied the privilege and Accordingly hung.

After hanging Pullins Pennick proceeded two or three miles further, and found two men sitting in a widow's door.
He asked them if they knew of the whereabouts of any bushwhackers.
Upon being answered in the negative be proceeded a short distance, when he was attacked and his regiment repulsed by men concealed in the brush.--Pennick immediately returned to the widow's house hung the two men he had seen there, and burned the widow's house.
Crossing the river into Jackson county, nominally in search of Quantrel, some of his men arrested a boy who was taking clothes to Quantrels command.
They went to the house of the boy's mother, (who was a widow.) seized and hung both her and her son. This man, Pennick, disgraces the position of the Most Worshipful Grand Master of the Masonic fraternity in Missouri.

Col. Boyd, of St. Joseph, and Capt. Hart, who so gallantly upheld the standard of Missouri during the campaign of 1861-62, died of wounds received at Independence last August.
They were Confederate officers.
Henry M. Voorhees, Esq., was defeated as the pro-slavery candidate for the Legislature by the Abolitionists and weak kneed Southerners.

In Clinton county, the notorious James H. Birch in "cavorting" as usual.
James H. Birch Jr., is in command of Plattsburg.

The prices of articles will look strange to some in the South.
Crops of every description were abundant — better than for several years.
Corn sells at $1,25 per barrel of five bushels, pork $2,50, bacon 6c to 8, coffee 50, sugar 25, wheat 70, hemp $3 to 3,50, tobacco high and stock of all kinds commanding a high price.
Gold is very , but "green-backs" are very abundant and at a heavy discount.

All the county seats are garrisoned by militia, the Federal troops having been entirely withdrawn.
This gentleman thinks it the height of folly for Missourians to think of returning home until our army is thrown into the State.

He says, also, that the families of all absent Southern soldiers are well attended to, and are not permitted to suffer for any of the comforts of life.
No Missouri soldier fear that his family is in want of anything to render them comfortable.

div4.head: Military execution in North Carolina.
div4.p:
Michael Dryant, a member of 63d regiment N C cavalry, was shot at Kinston last week for desertion — He was about 36 years of age, and had left his regiment but not to go to the enemy.
The correspondent of the Charleston Courier gives the following description of the scene at the execution:

It was not until the morning of his execution that the poor fellow became aware of the day or hour that was to terminate his career, but he had evidently been prepared for the crisis, and when the fact was announced it felt upon a heart nerved to brave death come in what shape it might.
And this composure never left him. Reaching the place of execution, which was in a field adjoining the encampment of his old command, the halted in front of an ominous-looking black coffin, behind which was a stake.
The guard alighted, and the prisoner, strong and buoyant as if he was the least among the actors of the drama, also leaped lightly from the vehicle and took his seat upon the narrow box that was so soon to enclose him forever.
An officer than advanced and bound him by the arms firmly with his back to the stake.
I now had an opportunity of observing the prisoner more closely.
He was clad in an every-day suit of citizens' clothes, with his pantaloons carelessly tucked in the top of his boots, and as he sat there watering the preparations for the dy, looking upon the faces of his old comrades with whom he had been associated in camp and field, alone and helpless with the agony of death so near, and sternity already opening to his vision the observer would have failed to detect the faintest indications of tremor on his person — Stern, strong calm as a Gatur, he waited until the regiment, on foot, was fired into position before him.

After a lapse of six minutes came the squad of twelve, who were to act as his executioners and stood 12 paces distant.
The Adjutant of the regiment then read the verdict of the Court- Martial.--This done, one of the guard approached to tie a handkerchief over the face of the prisoner.
Then, for the first time, did I notice anything in his bearing which seemed to indicate that he was not already totally dead to feeling.
A glance of his eyes to the Heavens, as if he was invoking Divine mercy, a barely perceptible change of countenance, and an expression of unutterable sadness, told of a fearful struggle that was going on within.
A moment's pause, and the officer in command, in a low tone, gave the order "Ready, aim, (twelve rifles six with blank cartridges, were bearing on the prisoner's heart, and the click of the twelve triggers left but a second between the life and death,) fire!"

Hardly had the smothered word issued from the lips when the body of the unfortunate man pierced by six balls, shrunk convulsively from the shock, the head dropped upon the breast, and a deep sigh told of an life.
The Surgean of the regiment now advanced to feel the palse, and at the same instant the Colonel exclaimed, "Attention." Half a minute had already elapsed, but at that word the dying man raised his bandaged head, and, as if he was peering through the darkness to take a long last look at the fading world, slowly turned it from side to side.
Then dropping it upon his breast it rested there for several seconds while the awe-stricken spectators looked on with a silence that was disturbed only by the rustling wind.--Again it arose and fell, and again, and again, until finally the short spasmodic gasps, succeeded by a death like repose showed that the soul of the deserter had returned to the God who gave it. One ball had entered at the base of the neck, two the left, and three the right side.

div4.head: Geo. D. Prentice engaged in cotton Speculating — he Gets Bitten.
div4.p: Among the Yankee correspondence captured by Gen. Wharton in his recent dash near Nashville, the following letter from Geo. D. Prentice, which explains itself:

div5.p:
Some months ago Mr. John W. White received from me five the dollars in gold, which me in cotton, investing, at the same time, a large amount for himself and others.
The cotton bales were seized at Nashville and used for the fortifications, Government receipts being given for them.
They are there yet, I learn.

"Now, it seems to me that when cotton is so very valuable-- a bale being worth, say, two hundred and forty dollars--that cheaper material ought long since to have been substituted in the fortifications.
The cotton, I am told is scandalously wasted by the soldiers, I have written a brief article for my paper on the subject, and I will have a copy sent to you. I bag that you will give article thought to my suggestions.
It is a sad thing for a to have to sustain a pecuniary loss in such illness as those.

div4.head: The Yankee Minister's Management of Diplomacy in England.
div4.p: The following is a copy of a dispatch from Chas. Francis Adams, U. S. Minister at England to Secretary Seward:

div5.head: [no. 243.] Legation of the U. States,
div5.p:
--About the time of writing my dispatch No. 237, I was considering in my mind the expediency of asking a conference with Lord Russell, in order to know whether the speech of Mr. Gladstons was to be regarded by me as conveying to the public the views of her Majesty's Government.
But as I was just then on the point of executing a promise I had made to visit Mr. W. M. Forster at his places, in York, I determined to put off a decision, at least until after my return to London, In the meantime I have had the opportunity of free conversation with that gentleman, whose capacity, judgment, and , in the of American questions in ment, have for him much of his respect and regard.
The conclusions to might have commerce, however, greatly mod the events which happened during the in of my stay.

It became apparent to me that Mr. Gladstone had been expressing his individual opinions and giving to his personal sympathy with the chief of the rebel whilst his source was regarded by several of his colleagues as the line of policy formerly agreed upon the time of their disportion for the summer.
The indication of this took the shape of notice in the Globe, an evening newspaper protecting neutrality in our struggle, and used for that reason to express official opinions, which, not without a little sharpness towards Mr. Gladstone, drew a clear line between him and the ministry in regard to the sentiments in his speech.
The next and more marked proof is to be in the report of a speech made by Sir George Comwall Lewis, and published in the morning papers, which is designed to neutralize the which mights have been and which, in undoubtedly were, drawn of an actual change in the Cabinet policy.

Putting these things together, I was led to the belief that it was wiser for me not to meddle with the matter at all just now, but rather to let it blow over, as a nine days' wonder.
I prefer to avoid any appearance of anxiety or of distruction the sincerity of the profession thus for still more any proceeding which might be natory, I shall therefore, let this week pass away without making any sign of of what is going on.

On the other hard, the feet is very certain that the departure of Lord Lyons has been again postponed.
The last time saw him he announced to me that he should go on the 11th.
Yet he is still here, and there is no sign of his immediate moving.
Concurrently with this delay, corses a notice that the first Cabinet Council is called for the 2 inst., which is earlier than usual, and intimation appear that one reason for this anticipation is the urgent nature of the American difficulty.
Without putting too much stress on these authorized conjectures, it is perfectly feir to incurr some connection between the approximation of the Cabinet meeting and the postponement of Lord Lyon's return.
I do not, therefore, doubt that the opportunity will be taken to reconsider the situation, and to lay down the like of policy for the regulation of the Minister of during the subsequent season.
How far the question of a recognition of the insurgents will enter into the deliberation.
I will not venture to prodict.
My own opinion is that that event now depends almost entirely on the fortune of the war. If we prove ourselves by February next no more able to control its results than we are at this moment, it will be difficult for Ministers longer to resist the current of sentiment leaning in that direction in both houses of Parliament.
I do not know that many of them will be longer inclined to do so-- Even the unpleasant alternative of appearing to uphold slavery against the action of a free Government will be acquiesced in as an overruling necessity, distaten by the popular opinion.
I feel it my duty to say thus much in order to prevent the smalliest misconception of the existing state of things on this side in the minds of the Government at home.

But it has occurred to me that, prior to this day of meeting, it may be expedient for me to solicit an interview with Lord Russell to dispose of other matters which have been left pending for some time past.
I may then be able incidentally to open a way to the subject most interesting to both countries, and to invite informal disclosures, if any are to be made, as well as in the same way to intimate probabilities which may in certain contin gencies that can be imagined. The matter requires are treatment; but as at present advised I am inclined to venture upon the experiment.-- Whatever the results of it may be I shall endeavor to lay them faithfully before you in my next.

closer.signed: Secretary of State, Washington, D. C.

div4.head: Sentences in Burnside's army.
div4.p: A letter from Burnside's army gives the following samples of the Court Martial sentences prevailing there:

q.p:
One private soldier, "for misbehavior before the enemy," was sentenced to forfeit all pay due him except just dues to his laundress and sutler, and all pay that may become due him during his term of service, and to be confined at hard labor.
A like sentence was passed upon another man for offering violence to his superior officer." A corporal, "for absenting himself from his company and regiment before the enemy at Fredericksburg" was reduced to the grade of private, forfeit pay due or that may become due, and was condemned to serve the balance of his term at hard labor.
A man for "skulking during the battle of Fredericksburg," was condemned to match before his regiment, having a board lashed to his back with the word "coward" on it, and to be put to hard labor with bill and chain attached to his leg.

div4.head: Empress Eugene's New Year's reception.
div4.p: The Paris correspondent of the N. Y. World gives an interesting account of the New Year's reception given by the Empress of France:

Her Majesty were a mantle of imperial purple trimmed with a wide border of erucine.
This mantle, unlike all the others, fall from the shoulders and was fastened with diamonds.
Her was of white it . She wore a and necklace of diamonds, the tiara having been newly set in what is called the Greece or Trojan wall pattern.
The train in all other cases is of the same material as the corsage of the dress and is made twice the usual rengts of the skirt.
The Princess Mattide wore a train of cloth of gold trimmed with two rows of Russian sable; her neck, arms, and head wore glittering with brilliants.
Her highness is said to possess the most valuable diamonds in France.
The Princess Cloulds wore a pink silk train and petticoat of the same material, both trimmed with tutle, looped alternately with roses and bunches of ribbons; her ornaments were also diamonds.
The Princess Metternich's toilet was so very magnificent that the Empress expressed her pleasure at it. It consisted of a cherry velvet mantle, embroidered about half a yard deep with silver; her was of white covered with lace, and her diamonds, some of which the only is ely came into possession of are said to be some of the finest in Europe--Lady Cowley, the wife of the England Embassador, being still in half-mourning for Prince Albert, wore a mauve colored train, with white petticoat trimmed with black lace with the diamonds and feathers which are the usual English court dress.
Another handsome dress wore on that occasion was a satin couieur cuir de Russie, trimmed with black and white lace, the pattic at being of mile over white , and trimmed to match with black lace.

In the evening receptions the court mantle, or train, is required to be worn by the lacies --the Empress having revived this discarded custom.
The wives of the embassadors, of the foreign ministers and secretaries are first received her majesty passing round and addressing some gracious words to each lady.
After this ceremony, her majesty goes into the Salie du Trone and reactives her French subject seated — these latter being obliged to pass through the ordeal of advancing and retreating gracefully in their appendage.
The ladies of the diplomatic corps, carry their trains upon their arms, except for the few minutes which are passed in the Empress's presence.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p:
Gen. Wool has ordered all the New York militia to repot to him. Upon hearing this, Gen. Hall, commander of the State for entered a vigorous protest.
This step has created great excitement.
The prevailing opinion is, that it is the design of the Administration to take the militia under its control.

A correspondent of the London Times says a child would instructively rush to Gen. Lee in a crowd as friend and protector, so fascinating is the beauty of his countenance; and adds that Gen. Lee dreads a new paper panegyric worse than he does a wound.
He says Lee is a here, but Jackson is a saint.

div3.head: The flag of truce,
div3.p:
--There is reason to believe that the flag-of-truce boat from Fortress Monroe to City Point is a Yankee trick for introduction spies, particularly female , into this country.
The editor of the South Carolinian says:

q.p:
On a recent trip on the South Carolina railroad we were thrown to with a number of female refugees (?) who had come from the North by the flag-of-truce boat to City Point.
In conversation with several of him, we learned that many Yankee women, who have never been in the South, are visiting their husbands, and who expect to return.
They report that the people of the North are sick of the war, but expect us shortly to surrender from starvation.

div3.p:
We had supposed the object of the flag of truce permits was to persons returning to their dom and had no idea that Northern women whose husbands had been caught in our workshops within the war commenced were to be allowed to visit them.
It may be all well but they certainly should not be allowed to communicate again with the North until the war is over.

We have reason to believe that many improper persons arrived by the last flag of truce beat.
Six hundred women are said to have come.
The Charleston Courier says:

q.p:
We have good reasons for suspecting, if not believing, that many spelt and doubtful characters, and some females, not of doubtful but of decidedly had repute, are among the subjects of the late flag-of-truce.
We shall not at present give further certain , but that a strict watch be kept over all who have recently arrived within our lines and are not well known.
We have been too often betrayed by the credulous courtesy accorded to flags of truce and to female apparel.

div3.head: Deserter to be that.
div3.p:
--John Mulligan, of company C, 5th.
Virginia cavalry, will be shot to-day at Camp Lee, in of the sentence of a Court-Martial, for the office of desertion and substitution, between the hours of 11 and 3 o'clock--Preparations were made for the execution yesterday, the party being detailed, coffin for the condemned ordered, &c. Mulligen has been reprieved on several occasions.
His is said to have been an aggravated case of desertion, having been arrested after leaving the army no less than three times in this city, and returned to his companions in arms.

div3.head: Desertion Recorded.
div3.p:
--A young man named Byron M. Bernard by occupation a telegraphic operator who, about a year since was placed in the city jail where he remained several months, as a character, he having betrayed the confidence of the Governor, who had intrusted him with a special mission, and who was afterwards released, joined the Richmond Light Infantry and was captured at Roanoke Island, and after being exchanged was employed as account by the Wise Legion and after that as a clerk or draughts man in the office of Major Gen. Gostaves W. Smith and who found it expedient to Richmond under peculiar circumstances, has lately turned up in Washington.
D. C., as a defensive of the Lincoln Government.
We conversed yesterday with a gentleman just from the seat of the abolition Government, where father had been lodged in the Capitol prison for disloyally by this scoundrel and renegade.

div3.head: Arrests.
div3.p:
--The city police Yesterday arrested and caged who will be brought before the Mayor this morning.
Among the number were James G. Duffy, Baptist Been's and Charles Johnson, charged by Thomas Moser with feloniously and by force and violence, robbing him of $60 in O. S. Treasury . Their captured by Messrs Perrin, Morris and Ch William, slave of Wm Barrett, was locked up by Officer John W. Davis for stealing a pair of fire from Harvey & Reynolds.
Late yesterday evening John A Johnson, as lad, was put in the cage for stealing a uniform coat from William B Wrenn.
Thos H. Bolster, for getting drunk and lying on the sidewalk; and Hudlow a free negro for being without his register and very drunk.

div3.head: Prison items.
div3.p:
--The following arrivals were chronicled at Castle Thunder on yesterday: Rendolph Gibson, of the Albemarle Artillery, for having a forged furlough, seat down by the Provost Marshal of Staunton;) Geo Semple, sent from the Libby Prison for misconduct; A Scott, La Guard Artilleries, and , 14th La sent by Capt. Booter for medical treatment, Wm. Morrow, sent up by Major Wise, supposed to have been trading with the Yankees.
The following discharges were made yesterday: Twenty-eight men, sent to Petersburg in charge of Colonel Moore, of the 19th Virginia regiment, to rejoin their regiments; Geo. T. Mathews sent to Battery No. 4 to his company; Wm. H Clay, who was sent by a Surgeon from the H ward Grove Hospital, December 22d for obstreperous conduct was honorably discharged, Solomon Fisher and L. Dickinson, committed some time since for harboring deserters near Christiansburg Montgomery county, were discharged by order of Gen. Winder, and furnished with transportation home; George W. White, arrested in Augusta county for supposed disloyally, was discharged, with directions, that he be sent to the Provost Marshal of Staunton, who was required to administer the oath to White and then parcel him on condition that he reside in Staunton Augusta, or some locality adjoining, where his Unionism would not be liberty to prove detrimental to the cause of the Confederacy.

div3.head: Opening of a lecture season.
div3.p:
--The opening of the lecture season of the Young Men's Christian Association takes place to night at the Broad Street Methodist Church.
The lecturer is Rev. Dr. Styles, several years ago a prominent minister in this city, and who, before the breaking out of the war, was officiating in New Haven, Ct. He is a native of Georgia, and from the commencement of this contest has been officiating of the Confederate army.
The subject of the lecture is "National Destitute the Bible basis of National Prosperity." The association has engaged other distinguished men, who will lecture through the season.

div3.head: Libby Prison.
div3.p:
--There were no arrivals at this prison yesterday.
Four of the inmates died on Wednesday.
There were in confinement yesterday 1,183 prisoners, distributed as follows: 912 Abolition prisoners of war; 203 citizen prisoners; 39 deserters from the Abolition army, and 29 negroes.
But two of the inmates of this prison were drowned on the occasion of the breaking of the 8th street bridge, and the bodies of both were recovered and decently inferred.

div3.head: Medical director.
div3.p:
--Surgeon Wm. A. Carrington is acting as Medical director of Major Gen. G. W. Smith's command, in place of Surgeon E. S. Gaillard, who is now on furlough.
Surgeon Carrington has charge of all the hospitals in this city and all reports of said hospitals are made to his office.

div3.head: Gen. Elasy.
div3.p: --This distinguished officer has almost recovered from his severe wounds, and will in a few days be ready to take his command in the field.

div4.head: The Courts.
div4.p:
--Several of the legal tribunals were in session yesterday, but did nothing worthy of special notice.
The Judges of the Supreme Court were engaged in listening to arguments in pending cases.
Before Judge Lyons, Mr. Ould delivered an argument on behalf of the Government in the habeas corpus case of the Theodore Whitman.
In Judge Halyburton's Court several decrees were entered for the payment to the Receiver of money due to alien enemies, and in the same Court will be tried to-day a boy charged with robbing the mail between Pittsylvenia C. H. and Lynchburg.
--George Quaries, arrested by the police on Wednesday, on the charge of stealing a plug of tobacco from Geo. W. Grettar, underwent an examination for the ade offerred, and was acquitted.
Jim, slave of Charles M. Pleasants, arrested by watchman Granger for going at large, was committed by the Mayor for trial before the Hustings Court.

Reuben slave of the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad Company, arrested by the watch for having two pairs of shoes in his possession supported to have been stolen, expired how be came by them was ordered 39 lashes, and the shoes were retailed in order to be identified by the party from whom they were taken.

Aloys Swain was arraigned on the charge of feloniously forge as the name or Dr. Hugh W. Davis to a recognition on the Commissary Department C . S. A forth payment of one hundred and eighty dollars. Several witnesses of the alleged felony being absent, the case was of necessity by continued until Friday morning defendant being lodged in jet mean while.

div3.head: Later News from Texas.
div3.p: --The Houston Telegraph of the 7th instant contains the following proclamation from General Magruder, which was sent out in neutral vessel to a neutral port:

div4.head: Proclamation.
div4.p: --Whereas, the undersigned has succeeded in capturing and destroying a portion of the enemy's fleet and in driving the remainder out of the harbor of Galveston and beyond the neighboring waters, and the blockade has been thus effectually raised, he therefore to all concerned that the harbor of Galveston is open for trade to all friendly nations, and their merchants are invited to resume their usual commercial intercourse with this port.
Done at Galveston this the fourth day of Jan'y, 1863.
The Telegraph gives the following Texas items:

The Federals at Sabine Pass run off every night and returned by day to the blockade.
They have given up the Pass.
We are in full possession.
The Dan, which they had up as a gunboat, has fallen into our hands and been destroyed.
Thus every place in our State that has been taken by the enemy has been redeemed and to day the Federal flag floats over not a foot of the sacred soil of Texas.

The Victoria Advocate says that a pair of large camels are being put on the express from the Rio Grands to Victoria.
They are to be harnessed to a large two-wheeled cart.
They will carry 3,000 pounds of freight, and make the trip in five to seven days.

The Confederate force on the 1st was 3,000 men, but a small portion of which was in the action — They had 3 guns, all sold, on shore and on gunboats, 21 of which were light artillery.
The enemy had six war steamers, mounting 40 heavy guns.
The Galveston city sexton buried 28 persons up to the 3d of whom 17 were killed in the fight and 11 died subsequently.
Gen. Magruder has issued a call for 2,000 more negroes to work upon the fortifications at Galveston.
Confederate bonds are now being taken up at the rate of over $100,000 a day in Houston.

div3.head: Invitation to leave.
div3.p: --Mr. Ten Eyck, of New Jersey, in a speech in the Lincoln Senate recently, raid that as the army was disintegration every step should be taken to increase in a length-- Some fifty thousand troops would are long be disbanded, and some eight thousand officers were absent, including some five hundred without leave, and if things went on in the way, unless proper measures should be taken, he would not be surprised if Lee should come and give us an invitation to leave before the 4th of March.
Miss Ida Vernon was presented with a magnificent act of jewelry, set with pearls, upon the close of her engagement at Montgomery, Ala., in
Wm. of Amherst county, lost the of
Gen. Joseph E. Johnston will command the army of Middle Tennessee in person.

div3.head:
A steamer captured by the blockaders.
Important dispatches saved.
div3.p:
--The steam propeller Princess--Royal, Captain Lawson from Glasgow, via London, (where she took on her cargo) St. Johns Halifax, and Be made having left the latter portion Friday, the 23d instant, was captured at an early hour this morning off this port by the Yankee blockaders.
She was suddenly surrounded by a number of the fleet before daylight and the officers had to run her on the beach off Long Island as the best resource left to them.
During yesterday the light draft Yankee steamers got a row line to her and succeeded in getting her off the batch before high water.

Capt. Thos. Cray, the Charleston pilot, Mr. Werton, a passenger, of Georgetown, S. C. and two other persons, escaped from her in a boat, and reached the city last evening.
Valuable dispatches, which were on heard the Princess Royal from Captain Maury, C. S. N., in Europe, to the Confederate States Government, have been saved out brought to this city.

The Princess Royal had on board a charge of great value to the Confederacy, consisting of nery for gunboats, Whitworth guns rifles powder and some , who were person bore in reference to the of new projectives.
The bulk of her freight was about 200 tons weight and measurement.

Captain Lawson was sick in the cabin at the time of her capture.
She had a terrible voyage, experiencing terrific gales in high Northern latitudes, and was compelled to put into St. John's Halifax, and Burmads, in order to obtain supply of coal.

The steamer Cornella, from Wilmington, N. C., had arrived safety at Barmuda.
The steamer Merrino, was still there they bring the only vessels in port.
The steamers Childs and Nines had sailed from Nassau.
The steamer Giraffs had arrived there from Wilmington.
Capt. L. M. Murrey, well known at the former commander of the steamship Nashville, has arrived in this city.

div3.head: From Vicksburg.
div3.p:
--The correspondence of the Advertiser, dated Vicksburg, 26th, says 5,000 Yankees are working on the canal opposite.
Their intention is to float their transports through when the river rises and land troops below the city.--Our defences below Vicksburg, however, are strong as above.
No immediate attack is expected here.
The greater part of the transports have gone up the river for reinforcements.
No belligerent demonstration will be made until their return Meantime we are strengthening the weak points along our lined.
The force of the enemy's fleet is 137 boats, 92 transports, and 14 gunboats.
There may be more arrivals of gunboats before the fight begins.
The strength of the Yankee army will probably be 80,000.
No new movements of the enemy observed this morning.

div3.head: Interesting decision.
div3.p: --The Supreme Court has decided that a conscript under the first law, who obtained a substitute now liable to conscription under the new law, also becomes liable to enrollment.

div3.head: Arrival of Another steamer
div3.p: --Still another steamer, with a full cargo of merchandize and munitions of war, from Nassau, arrived at a Confederate for last night.

div3.head: North Carolina Legislature.
div3.p: --The "ten regiment bill" was defected in the Senate to-day by a vote of 18 yeas to 27 nays.

div3.head:
By Benson & pro., Auct'rs,
[Charlottesville, Va.]
Commissioner's Sale of Twenty Slaves.
div3.p: --I will sell at public auction, on Monday, Feb'y 2, 1863, (Albemarle Court day,) in the town of Charlottesville--
Twenty Slaves,
Eighteen of whom are young and likely.
div3.closer:
Jas. D. Jones, Com'r.
Sale by Benson & Bro., Aucts. ja 27--dt*

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 26, page 2.

div3.head: Prospects of peace.
div3.p:
If we meet with no great and unexpected disasters; if we do not relax our exertions, the war must virtually be ended by the 1st of June. All the signs of the times, the ascendency of the Democratic party at the North, the partial failure of their draft, and the entire emation of volunteering; the admission by them that a large part of their army goes out of service to May, and that no now recruits can be had to supply their player; the frequent and numerous desertions from their army, their domestic dissention their bitter denunciations of Lincoln, his Cabinet the Abolitionists, and of all New England; the imminence of national bankruptcy, the ruin of their shipping and commercial interests, and incipient social anarchy, all prove that they can keep up the war but a few months longer.
Besides, they know that foreign intervention, however delayed, must come at last No doubt they desire it, in order to have a protext for backing out from the contest.
Even Horace Greeing admits that they must conquer us in three months, or then make the best peace they can — Indeed, whether between individuals or nations, a big fight must over be a short fight; because the parties, putting out all their strength at once, soon become exhausted.
The North is exhausted.--Every one who wants to have a hand in this glorious war should enlist at once or else an early peace may deprive them of the opportunity of helping to win the independence of the South.

div3.head: Exeter Hall.
div3.p:
The only class of the English people who sympathize with the Lincoln despotism are the men who get themselves up as the expected champions of universal freedom, and who derive their law and gospel in religion and morals from Exeter Hall.
The nobility and gentry the cultivation and refinement of Great Britain, are with the South; the fanaticism, ignorance, and vulgarity, with the North.
Puritanism is the same in all countries, and speaks with the same voice in Exeter Hall and Reecher's Tabernante.
It possible, the English Puritans are even more besotted and intolerant than their Yankee progeny and kinfolk.
Always envious of their superiors in rank and station, always claiming a monopoly of virtue and righteousness, they may naturally be expected to side with New England in an abolition war — a war which had its origin in Exeter Hall, and which, it unsuccessful, will be the death of Endicatism in Great Britain as well as America.

div3.head: C. S. Army.
div3.p:
--The Quartermaster General's report shows that in the Confederate States army we have 200 Generals, 163 Brigade Quartermasters, 100 Brigade, Commissaries, 500 Chaplains, 300 companies of artillery, 78 regiments of cavalry, and 481 regiments of infantry.
In the navy we have 4 Admirals, 10 Captains, 31 Commanders, 100 First Lieutenants 25 Second Lieutenants, 20 Masters to line of promotion, 12 Paymasters, 40 Assistant Paymasters, 22 Surgeons, 15 Passed Assistant Surgeons, 30 Assistant Surgeons, 1 Engineer-In-Chief, 12 Engineers, 20 Passed madshipmen, 106 acting Madshipmen, etc, and 5,000 seamen, ordinary seamen, landsmen boys, firemen and coal leavers.

div3.head: Type Wanted.
div3.p:
--The propriators of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Type.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: Notice to Fredericksburg sufferers.
div3.p:
--Since the 2d of December, 1863, when our labors commenced the Committee in Richmond, through their Treasurer, have expended the sum of $2,239.31, of which $4,070.30, have been paid for provisions and supplies, and $1,963.95 fund had in money to the Fredericksburg suffers or for their relief.
We now learn with pleasure that a large fund in money has been raised by the Mayor or Council of Fredericksburg from generous contributors, chiefly in the army, for the relief of the Fredericksburg people.
We also learn from correspondence with a member of the Council of Fredericksburg that they are of opinion that they can judge with more accurate discrimination and knowledge of the wants, necessitie, and condition of the sufferers then persons at a distance from that city.
We therefore give notice that hereafter all persons in and from Fredericksburg needing aid in money will apply to the Fredericksburg authorities.
The fund remaining under our control will all be needed for purchasing provisions and supplies to avert suffering during the winter and coming spring.
We hope the generous people of the South will continue to contributives heretofore.
div3.closer:
R. R. Rowison.
Treas Fred'g Relief Fund. []

div4.p: On Wednesday, 28th instant, at half-past 6 o'clk of consumption, Miss. Judy Arn Morrisett, of Hanover county, beloved wife of Mr. Severly Morrbett, and daughter of Mr. John Delany, aged 27 years. She has left as bereaved husband, two small children and a large number of friends to mourn their loss.
She was a kind and affectionate wife and a very daughter, and, above all, a pious Christian, and I trust that her friends may prepare to meet her in Heaven.

lg.l: Take this new treasure to thy breast;
And give these shared relief room
To slumier in the silent dust.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died in New London, Campbell county, Va., on Monday morning, January 19th 1863 Mrs. Maria Clagete Trust, relict of the late General George Rust, of London in the 74th year of her age.

The deceased was one of the oldest Episcopalians in this country, having been confirmed in her sixteenth year by her kinsman, Bishop Clagatt, of Maryland.
She was distinguished for her enable platy, and the modesty, sweetness, and gentleness of her disposition.
No one over lived more up to the communion requirement of being "in love and charity with your neighbors, " never suffering an unkind word to escape her lips, and she died, truly, without an enemy do earth.
After a long and useful life this devoted Christian has been called to a brighter and a better world to meet that God in whom she so fondly trusted from her youth up; and when death's summons came, realizing the precious promises of our Saving, and with a smile upon her face she uttered her last words. "Lord, I hear. " *

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Immediately, a Wet Nurse, without encumbrance, either white or colored.
To one who can come well recommended a good price will be given.
Apply to.
div3.closer:
L. E. Frayers, 19th st.
Between Main and Franklin. ja 30--6t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Woman of good character to Cook Wash, and Iron.
To such an one a comfortable home is offered.
Apply at my residence, on 12th street, between Broad and Marshal.

div3.head: Wanted — an Apprentice.
div3.p: --I wish to engage Boy, about 16 years of age, to learn the Creech Blacksmith business.
div3.closer:
Geo. A. Ains 13 Coach-maker,
10th st, betw Main and Cary. ja 30--2t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--To rent or purchase a small House, containing about four rooms, situated either in the suburbe of Richmond or Manchester.
A liberal price will be given.
Address 'Jones, ' at this office, stating location and price.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A furnished Room, in a private family, within fifteen minutes walk of the Capitol.
Address "W." through this office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A young man, 20 years of age, who has been honorably discharged from , wishes Employment in some profitable business.
Address "J. H." Richmond P. O.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--To hire a white Girl, to do house work.
I will pay a good price.
Apply to D. Sudiel, on Franklin street, near the corner of 25th.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A gentleman, wife, and two children wish Rooms and Board in a private family, or a small home or part of a house, with accommodation for cooking.
References exchange.
Address "A. B. C." Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --A No. I Washer and Ironer, (white preferred) Apply on the North side of Main street, first brick house above 31st.

Sr. Led Proposals will be received at this office until 2 o'clock. Wednesday, February 4th, 1863, for the building of fifty Houses for Hospitals, on the site known as Camp Dimmock, about half a raise west of Camp Winder.
Each house to be 80 feet long and 28 feet wide, 10 feet and floor 18 inches from the ground, shingled patch with two Venetian ventilators on each 4½ by ½ feet.
Twelve windows to each house, six-light cash, 12 by 1
Six doors to each house, with fastening complete.
One lattics Medicine Closet in each, 4 by 8 feet.
For further particulars bidders are referred to the buildings lately credited at Howard's Grow, as these are to be built exactly like them.
The buildings must be completed by the first of April, and the party to whom the work is awarded will be required to give approved bond and security for the faithful performance of the same.
div3.closer:
Wm. M. Warren, Capt. and A. Q. M.
Bank st 4th door from 9th. ja 30--4t*

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A likely young Negro Woman, without encumbrance.
She is a first rate course and House Servant, and a good Cook, Washer, and Ironer.

Also, a good Match Cow for sale.
Call on 7th street, third door from Clay.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A very liberal price will be paid for a Substitute, for a conscript.
None other but a discharged soldier, over forty-five years of age, need apply.
Call early, at 63 Main street.

div3.head: Read! read! read!--Twenty dollars Per day!
div3.p:
--A blockade runner has brought from the North the receipt of a celebrated Philadelphia firm for an absolutely indispensable article to every one.
Although simple in its ingredients, it commands the most extravagant and unnecessary prince throughout the entire South.

Particular attention is also called to a receipt from the same source which, in any branch of the army, would not only prove a joy to the soldier in his cold and dreary path, but a handsome income to the manufacturer.
At artrifling expense, both of money and labor, dealers in tonics of all anlants of any kind would do well to note the above.

No one can fail in the manufacture of either, as the directions are most explicit and simple.
Both receipts sent to any one sending 83, or either for 82.
Address.

div3.head:
Camp 44th Reg. Va. Infantry,
2d Brigade, 1st Division,
Jackson's corps, Jan, 20, 1863.
thirty dollars reward.
div3.p: --A reward of thirty dollars each will be paid for the arrest and delivery to me of any one of the following named deserters:
Louis ZecLOSKY, a German, with dark complexion, black eyes and hair, and about 5 feet 9 inches high with a slight stoop in the shoulders.
Deney Guike, a German, with blue eyes, fair complexion, Light hair, and about 5 feet 6 inches high.
John Furcell, an Irishmen, with blue eyes, gray hair fair complexion, about 5 feet 10 inches high, and about 45 years of age.
Alfred A Healy, blue eyes, dark hair, fair complexion, 5 feet 6 inches high, very spare in figure and about 13 years of age.
James L. Hayward blue eyes, light hair, sallow complexion, 5 feet 7 inches high, and about 19 years of age.
Henry Brockelman, a German, with blue eyes, light hair, fair complexion, 5 feet 10 inches high, and over 40 years of age.

closer.signed: Capt. Co. F, 44th Reg Va Infantry,

div3.p:
the undersigned members of my Company are deserters.
I will pay the usual fees to have them arrested:

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --All members of my company are hereby notified to meet at the rendezvous, corner of 7th and Broad sts to-Morrow evening, at 4 o'clock, ready to leave, on Wytheville.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For the war. A man over 45 years of age, and a citizen of the Confederate States, for which a liberal price will be given.
Call at the American Hotel, between the hours of 8 and 12 o'clock A. M., Room No. 1. 3.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For the war. A man over 45 years of age, and a citizen of the Confederate States, for which a liberal price will be given.
Call at the American Hotel, Room No. 22 between the hours of 8 and 12 o'clock A. M.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in the 12th Virginia reg't. He must be over 43 years of age, and well recommended.
One that will cut and will receive a liberal bonus.
Call at room No. 60, American Hotel, between the hours of 10 and 1 o'clock.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--Over 45 years old, of good character.
For such an one a liberal price will be paid.
Apply early to-day at my shop.
div3.closer:
C. O. Tinsley, on 7th street,
Bet Broad and Marshall. ja 30--2t*

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For one over 45 years old a liberal price will be paid.
Apply from 10 till 3 o'clock on Friday and Saturday, 30th and 31st January, at No. 292 Broad street 4th door above 1st.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p: --For the war. For a good and reliable man over 45 years of age, a liberal price will be paid by early application to Dr. Broocks, corner of Main and 12th sts.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in the 1st Maryland Artillery.
Highest each price paid.
Apply to Jas Perdue & Co, Manchester, Va.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p: --Over 45 years of age, to go in the 15th Virginia reg't. Apply at the Monticello House. No. 53 Main st.

div3.head: Three substitutes Wanted.
div3.p:
--Two thousand dollars each will be given.
Apply at the office of the Powhatan House.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A good, reliable man, over 45 years of age, will receive a liberal price for his services.
Apply at Hill's Ambrotype Gallery. 183 Broad st.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For the war. For a man of good character, over 45 years of age, and a citizen of the Confederacy, a liberal bonus will be paid.
Apply at the store of
div3.closer:
Robert R. Roberts.
Corner of Cary and 12th sts. ja 20--3t*

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--Over 45 years of age, who can give satisfactory references.
For such as one a liberal price will be paid.
Call on
P. A. Woods, 11th and Cary sts.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p: --Over 45 years. For a suitable man a liberal price will be paid.--Call at Williams & Carrington's office, corner 13th and Cary streets, between 9 A. M. and 2 P. M.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p: --A reliable man, to serve in a first class cavalry company, can obtain a good price by applying at.

Williams & Plliott's.
No. 67 Main street. ja 29--3t

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p: --A good man, over 45 years of age, is desired as a Substitute.--Call at Room No. 51, Columbian Hotel, to day.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--I wish to employ a Substitute.
For a good and reliable man, over 45 years old, a liberal price will be paid.
Apply next door to the Edgemont House, on Main, between 6th and 7th sts.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A good price will be paid for an acceptable Substitute, who is over 45 years of age, and can come well recommended.
Call for "Mr. T. C.," at the office of W. D. Tompkins & Bro, Basin Bank.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For a suitable man, over 45 years of age, a liberal price will be paid.
Apply at.
div3.closer:
J. C. Ellett's
Grocery, cor 5th and Marshall sts. ja 28--ts

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--Over the age of 45 years; a musician preferred.
Apply at 229 Main st.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For the 15th Regiment Va Cavalry, for which a good horse, saddle, and all necessary equipments will be furnished and a liberal price paid.
Apply at once at Ward A, General Hospital No. 12, corner of 19th and Franklin streets, between the hours of 9 and 3, till 31st January.
